generif.text: Biochemically characterized a hexamethylene bisacetamide-inducible protein HEXIM1, which is a novel nuclear protein. Interacts with p50 of NF-kB and suppresses NF-kB transcription.
MAQ1 cooperates with 7SK RNA to form a novel type of CDK inhibitor.
Binding of the 7SK snRNA turns the HEXIM1 protein into a P-TEFB (CDK9/cyclin T) inhibitor.
HEXIM1 and HEXIM2 exhibit distinct expression patterns in various human tissues
utilization of HEXIM1 or HEXIM2 to bind and inhibit P-TEFb can be differentially regulated in vivo.
Hexim1 has a cyclin T-binding domain and binds competitively to HIV-1 Tat
increased estrogen down regulated gene 1 expression results in inhibition of cyclin T1 recruitment and estrogen receptor 1 DNA binding
HEXIM1 forms a transcriptionally abortive complex with glucocorticoid receptor without involving 7SK RNA and positive transcription elongation factor b.
HEXIM1 dimer associates with only one molecule of RNA.

HIV-1 Tat transactivation is effectively inhibited by co-expression of HEXIM1; HEXIM1 expression specifically represses transcription mediated by the direct activation of P-TEFb through artificial recruitment of GAL4-CycT1
analysis of positive transcription elongation factor - HEXIM1 - 7SK RNA complex
Ectopic expression of HEXIM1 causes growth inhibition and promotes neuronal differentiation. These findings highlight a crucial role of HEXIM1 protein during cell differentiation.
the interplay between 7SK snRNA and oppositely charged regions in HEXIM1 direct its binding to P-TEFb and subcellular localization that culminates in the inhibition of transcription

Binding of HEXIM1 is a prerequisite for association of P-TEFb with the G302-C324 apical region of the 3' hairpin of 7SK that is highly reminiscent of the human immunodeficiency virus transactivation-responsive RNA.
Data show that the transcription-dependent dissociation of P-TEFb-HEXIM1-7SK RNA relies upon formation of hnRNP-7SK RNA complexes.
provide structural insights how Hexim1 recognizes the Cyclin T1 subunit of positive transcription elongation factor b
a mutant HEXIM1 protein that cannot be phosphorylated and released from P-TEFb and 7SK snRNA via the PI3K/Akt pathway antagonizes this HMBA-mediated induction of viral production.
NPM binds to HEXIM1 in vitro and in vivo, and functions as a negative regulator of HEXIM1.
HEXIM1 may act as a gene-selective transcriptional regulator via direct interaction with certain transcriptional regulators including glucocorticoid receptor.

HEXIM1 regulation on estrogen action showed a decrease in estrogen-stimulated recruitment of ERalpha, P-TEFb, and S2P RNAP II to promoter and coding regions of ERalpha-responsive genes pS2 and CCND1 with increased HEXIM1 expression in MCF-7 cells
HEXIM1 may participate in tissue-selective determination of glucocorticoid sensitivity via direct interaction with GR at least in certain gene sets including atp1a1 and scnn1a.
Ubiquitination of HEXIM1 protein increases the inhibitory ability of HEXIM1 protein on P-TEFb-dependent transcription, but does not lead to proteasome-dependent protein degradation of HEXIM1.
The tripartite protein-RNA complex formation between Hexim, Cyclin T and 7SK snRNA, was analyzed.
T-loop phosphorylated Cdk9 localizes to nuclear speckle domains which may serve as sites of active P-TEFb function and exchange between the Brd4 and 7SK/HEXIM1 regulatory complexes.
binding to Cyclin T1 induces an asymmetry or sterical hindrance in the first coiled coil segment of dimeric Hexim1 that disallows formation of a 2:2 complex.
data provide evidence to suggest a novel role for HEXIM1 in cancer progression
reincorporation of HEXIM1 into the 7SK snRNP is likely the regulated step of reassembly of the 7SK snRNP containing P-TEFb

Tat efficiently replaces HEXIM1 on the 7SK snRNA in vivo and it promotes the disassembly of the 7SK/HEXIM/P-TEFb negative transcriptional regulatory snRNP to augment the nuclear level of active P-TEFb.
Structural insights were provided into the recognition of the regulator protein Hexim1 by P-TEFb and the modulation of coiledcoil dynamics by specific discontinuities.

Changes in Hexim-1 protein expression and cellular distribution significantly influence androgen receptor activation and transforming growth factor (TGF)-beta signaling in prostate cancer progression.
N-terminal residues in cyclin T1 are specifically involved in the binding of cyclin T1 to HEXIM1 but not to Tat.
results not only identify HEXIM1 as a positive regulator of p53, but also propose a novel molecular mechanism of p53 activation caused by the anti-cancer drugs and compounds.
P-TEFb/HEXIM1-dependent transcriptional regulation may play a pathophysiological role in RVH and be a novel therapeutic target for mitigating RVH in PAH
This study demonstrates a novel role of HEXIM1 in regulating human pluripotent stem cells fate through a P-TEFb-independent pathway.
There is evidence for a direct interaction between HIF-1alpha and HEXIM1, and HEXIM1 up-regulated hydroxylation of HIF-1alpha.
the release of P-TEFb from the 7SK snRNP led to increased synthesis of HEXIM1 but not HEXIM2

HEXIM1 functions as an AR (androgen receptor) co-repressor as it physically interacts with the AR and is required for the ability of anti-androgens to inhibit androgen-induced target gene expression and cell proliferation.
Data indicate the binding of RNA-binding protein HEXIM with 7SKsnRNP complex comprising the non-coding RNA 7SK and proteins MePCE and LARP7.
PPM1G phosphatase directly binds 7SK RNA and the kinase inhibitor Hexim1 once P-TEFb has been released from the 7SK snRNP.

Suggest that greater tumor associated macrophage density, strong Hexim1 expression, strong SMAD2 expression, and mild SMAD7 expression play important roles in the progression of prostate adenocarcinoma.

Results show that HEXIM1 is a tumor suppressor in melanoma that responds to nucleotide stress by inhibiting transcription elongation of tumorigenic genes and stabilizing mRNA transcripts of other tumor suppressor genes.
HMBA and derivative HMBA4a1 induce HEXIM1 activity, targeting several signaling pathways critical in tumorigenesis and metastasis.
We conclude that the degradation of NPM1 and HEXIM1 through autophagy in certain AML subsets contributes to the activation of the BET pathway in these cells.
Our results demonstrated that HEXIM1 exhibited the most consistent response to BET inhibitors in all of the settings examined, including tumors and surrogate tissues.
HSP70 activator shows similar activity as HMBA and 4a1 to induce HEXIM1 expression, suggesting that HMBA and 4a1 might be putative HSP70 activators

Identify a HEXIM1-containing ribonuclear protein complex composed also of DNA-PK, paraspeckle subunits, and the long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) NEAT1, which acts as a key nuclear regulator of DNA-mediated activation of innate immune response through the cGAS-STING pathway.

The 7SK RNA binds to Hexim1 and turns it into an inhibitor of the positive transcription elongation factor (P-TEFb). And in addition to its action on P-TEFb, it plays a role in a variety of different mechanisms: it controls the stability of transcription factor components and assists binding of transcription factors to their targets.
Both HEXIM1 and RAD51 promote BET inhibitor-induced fork slowing but also prevent a DNA damage response.
HEXIM1 Diffusion in the Nucleus Is Regulated by Its Interactions with Both 7SK and P-TEFb.
Structural transitions in the RNA 7SK 5' hairpin and their effect on HEXIM binding have been reported.
Phosphorylation of the histone demethylase KDM5B and regulation of the phenotype of triple negative breast cancer.

HMBA and 4a1 induce HEXIM1 expression by inhibiting KDM5B. Upregulation of HEXIM1 expression levels plays a critical role in the inhibition of proliferation of breast cancer cells using KDM5B inhibitors.
HEXIM1 controls P-TEFb processing and regulates drug sensitivity in triple-negative breast cancer.
UHRF1 Suppresses HIV-1 Transcription and Promotes HIV-1 Latency by Competing with p-TEFb for Ubiquitination-Proteasomal Degradation of Tat.
Downregulation of Dihydrotestosterone and Estradiol Levels by HEXIM1.
HEXIM1 is an essential transcription regulator during human erythropoiesis.

BP.term: negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
negative regulation of transcription elongation by RNA polymerase II
negative regulation of transcription elongation by RNA polymerase II
negative regulation of cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase activity
positive regulation of signal transduction by p53 class mediator

MF.term: cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase inhibitor activity
cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase inhibitor activity

name: HEXIM P-TEFb complex subunit 1

wikipathways.name: Initiation of transcription and translation elongation at the HIV-1 LTR

summary: Expression of this gene is induced by hexamethylene-bis-acetamide in vascular smooth muscle cells. This gene has no introns. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
